sen.j: 焼肉（やきにく）とは、肉を焼網に乗せあぶったり、鉄板などで焼いたりした肉料理。
sen.e: Yakuniku refers to dishes in which meat is cooked on a grill or iron plate.
Yakuniku refers to dishes in which meat is cooked on a grill or iron plate.
Yakuniku refers to dishes in which meat is cooked on a grill or iron plate.

sen.j: 広義にはステーキ、ジンギスカン鍋、バーベキューなどを含める。
sen.e: The broad definition of the word encompasses grilled steaks and jingisukan.
The broad definition of the word encompasses grilled steaks and jingisukan.
The broad definition of the word encompasses grilled steaks, jingisukan and barbecue.

sen.j: 本項では主に「焼肉店」と称される店舗において展開され、肉を焼網などに乗せあぶって食べる料理について解説する。
sen.e: This article details yakiniku as meat cooked on a grill and sold at yakiniku restaurants in Japan.
This article details yakiniku as meat cooked on a grill and sold at yakiniku restaurants in Japan.
This article describes yakiniku as meat cooked on a grill and eaten at 'yakiniku restaurants' in Japan.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。クォーテーションを補足しました。

sen.j: 鉄板で焼く料理に付いては「鉄板焼き」で解説する。
sen.e: For an explanation of dishes in which ingredients are cooked using an iron plate, refer to the article "Teppanyaki".
For an explanation of dishes in which ingredients are cooked using an iron plate, refer to the article "Teppanyaki".
For an explanation of dishes in which ingredients are cooked using an iron plate, refer to the article "Teppanyaki."

sen.j: 概要
sen.e: Overview
Overview
Summary
sen.cmt: 他のトピックと合わせる

sen.j: 肉を焼く方法には、直火焼き（網焼き、串焼き等）と鉄板焼きとがある。
sen.e: Methods of cooking meat include jikabi-yaki (on a grill or skewer over an open fire) or teppan-yaki (on an iron plate).
Methods of cooking meat include jikabi-yaki (on a grill or skewer over an open fire) or teppan-yaki (on an iron plate).
Methods of cooking meat include jikabi-yaki (on a grill or skewer over an open fire) or teppan-yaki (on an iron plate).

sen.j: 直火焼きは、焼くときに脂が滴り落ち表面がカリッと仕上がるので比較的さっぱりとした味となる。
sen.e: The jikabi-yaki method allows fat to drip down, giving the surface of the meat a crispy texture and a relatively fresh flavor.
The jikabi-yaki method allows fat to drip down, giving the surface of the meat a crispy texture and a relatively fresh flavor.
The jikabi-yaki method allows fat to drip down, giving the surface of the meat a crispy texture and a relatively fresh flavor.

sen.j: また、火で直接炙るので焦げ目がつきやすく、落ちた脂による煙で多少燻されるので香ばしい風味となる。
sen.e: Grilling directly over a fire causes meat to readily brown and the fat that drips down leads to a slight smoking effect, which creates a fragrant taste.
Grilling directly over a fire causes meat to readily brown and the fat that drips down leads to a slight smoking effect, which creates a fragrant taste.
Grilling directly over a fire causes meat to readily brown and the fat that drips down leads to a slight smoking effect which adds a smoky taste.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 一方、鉄板焼きは脂が落ちにくい為コクのある味となる。
sen.e: On the other hand, cooking using an iron plate makes it difficult for the fat to escape and leads to a rich taste.
On the other hand, cooking using an iron plate makes it difficult for the fat to escape and leads to a rich taste.
In contrast, cooking using an iron plate makes it difficult for the fat to escape and leads to a rich taste.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: また、直火で炙られることが無いため水分が飛びづらく、柔らかな食感となる。
sen.e: The absence of an open fire means that the ingredients do not lose as much water and retain a soft texture.
The absence of an open fire means that the ingredients do not lose as much water and retain a soft texture.
The absence of an open fire means that the ingredients retain water and a soft texture.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 日本における焼肉の味付けは、醤油を基本に日本酒、砂糖、ニンニク、ゴマなどを調合して作った配合調味料（焼肉のたれ）を使うものと、塩やコショウ、レモン等で味付けをするものが一般的である。
sen.e: Yakiniku seasonings generally used in Japan include a sauce (yakiniku no tare) which is a comprised of ingredients such as soy sauce rice wine; sugar; garlic and sesame, as well as salt, black pepper and lemon.

Yakiniku seasonings generally used in Japan include a sauce (yakiniku no tare) which is a comprised of ingredients such as soy sauce, rice wine, sugar, garlic and sesame, as well as salt, black pepper and lemon.
Yakiniku seasonings generally used in Japan include a sauce (yakiniku no tare) which is a comprised of ingredients such as soy sauce, rice wine, sugar, garlic and sesame, salt, pepper and lemon.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。表現を変えました。

sen.j: 海外でもTeppanyaki/Yakinikuとして広まりつつある。
sen.e: Teppanyaki and yakiniku are becoming increasingly well known around the world.
Teppanyaki and yakiniku are becoming increasingly well known around the world.
Teppanyaki and yakiniku are becoming increasingly well known around the world.

sen.j: 日本式だけでなく、韓国式のメニューも含める。
sen.e: Includes Japanese and Korean ingredients.
Includes Japanese and Korean ingredients.
Includes Japanese and Korean ingredients.

tit.cmt: 文頭以外の語頭を小文字に
文頭以外の語頭を小文字に

sen.j: 焼肉の起源は日本であると考えられている。
sen.e: Yakiniku is thought to have originated in Japan.
Yakiniku is thought to have originated in Japan.
Yakiniku is thought to have originated in Japan.

sen.j: 肉を焼いて食べるという基本的な調理法である為に、起源には様々な説が存在するが、2001年のNHK人間講座で「焼肉は韓国文化と思いがちだが、戦後の日本が生んだ食文化である」と放送された。
sen.e: As yakiniku is basically the grilling of meat, the are various theories regarding its origin but an edition of Ningen Koza broadcast in 2001 stated that "although often believed to be part of Korean culture, yakiniku actually originated in Japan after the Second World War".

As yakiniku is basically the grilling of meat, there are various theories regarding its origin but an edition of Ningen Koza broadcast in 2001 stated that "although often believed to be part of Korean culture, yakiniku actually originated in Japan after the Second World War".

As grilling is a basic cooking method, there are various theories regarding its origin but an edition of Ningen Koza of Japan Broadcasting Corporation in 2001 stated that 'although often believed to be part of Korean culture, yakiniku actually originated in Japan after the World War II.'
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: （朝鮮・韓国における日本起源否定の流れの一つに）別冊BUBKA2006年7月号33ページに「焼肉」の起源は日本であるが、日本発祥といえども始めたのは朝鮮人であるという説が掲載された。
sen.e: On page 33 of the July 2006 supplement edition of the magazine BUBKA, it is stated (as one of a wave of denials in Korea of a Japanese origin) that "Yakiniku originated in Japan but even though its place of origin can said to be Japan, it was Korean people actually who created it".

On page 33 of the July 2006 supplement edition of the magazine BUBKA, it is stated (as one of a wave of denials in Korea of a Japanese origin) that "Yakiniku originated in Japan but even though its place of origin can said to be Japan, it was Korean people actually who created it".

On page 33 of the July 2006 supplement edition of the magazine called BUBKA, it is stated (as one of a wave of denials in Korea of a Japanese origin) that 'Yakiniku' originated in Japan but even though its place of origin can said to be Japan, it was Korean residents of Japan who actually created it.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。クォーテーションの位置などを変えました。

sen.j: 戦前に捨てるか肥料にするかしていた臓物肉を朝鮮人女工がもらってきて焼いて食べたのがホルモン焼きの始まりであり、ホルモンを焼いて食べる習慣は朝鮮にはなく、ホルモン焼きは日本で始まった。
sen.e: The argument is that offal which before the Second World War had been either discarded or used as fertilizer was grilled and eaten by Korean female factory workers in Japan to become what is now known as horumonyaki, and that therefore the custom of grilling offal originated not in Korea but Japan.

The argument is that offal, which before the Second World War had been either discarded or used as fertilizer, was grilled and eaten by Korean female factory workers in Japan to become what is now known as horumonyaki, and that therefore the custom of grilling offal originated not in Korea but Japan.

The argument is that offal, which before the World War II had been either discarded or used as fertilizer, was grilled and eaten by Korean female factory workers in Japan and became what is now known as horumonyaki, and that therefore the custom of grilling offal (small intestine) originated not in Korea but Japan.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: そして戦後、ホルモン焼きの屋台が「ホルモン屋」や「朝鮮料理屋」という名称になって行く中、新宿にミノやセンマイといったホルモンだけでなくロースやカルビなどの精肉を用いる店が出来る。
sen.e: After the war, as stalls selling horumonyaki became referred to as "horumonyaki-ya" or "chosen ryori-ya" (lit. Korean food shop), restaurants arose in Shinjuku which sold high quality meat in addition to offal such as beef rumen and omasum.

After the war, as stalls selling horumonyaki became referred to as "horumonyaki-ya" or "chosen ryori-ya" (lit. Korean food shop), restaurants arose in Shinjuku which sold high quality meat in addition to offal such as beef rumen and omasum.

After the war, while stalls selling horumonyaki became referred to as 'horumonyaki-ya' or 'chosen ryori-ya' (lit. Korean food shop), restaurants started business in Shinjuku which sold high quality meat such as sirloin and beef ribs in addition to small intestine such as mountain chain tripe and bible tripe.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: この在日朝鮮人女性が経営する明月館が焼肉の祖であるとするのが同誌の主張である。
sen.e: This publication claims that the Meigetsukan restaurant run by these Korean women in Japan that was the origin of yakiniku.
This publication claims that the Meigetsukan restaurant run by these Korean women in Japan was the origin of yakiniku.
This publication claims that the Meigetsukan restaurant run by Korean women in Japan was the origin of yakiniku.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: さらに同誌は、「焼肉」と呼称するようになったのは1965年に日本国と大韓民国との間の基本関係に関する条約が結ばれ、韓国籍に移る者が増え、在日朝鮮人の主張した朝鮮料理屋と在日韓国人の主張した韓国料理屋との呼称論争を収拾する案としてプルコギを直訳した「焼肉」が用いられることとなったのだとの説を主張している。
sen.e: It goes on to state the theory that the dish became named "yakiniku" when the Treaty on Basic Relations between Japan and the Republic of Korea signed in 1965 led to an increase in the number of people converting from the Joseon (old, undivided Korea) nationality to South Korean nationality increased, and the word "yakiniku" became used as a direct translation of "bulgogi" as a proposed resolution to a dispute regarding naming that occurred between Korean restaurants operated by Joseon Koreans and those operated by South Koreans.

It goes on to state the theory that the dish became named "yakiniku" when the Treaty on Basic Relations between Japan and the Republic of Korea signed in 1965 led to an increase in the number of people converting from the Joseon (old, undivided Korea) nationality to South Korean nationality increased, and the word "yakiniku" became used as a direct translation of "bulgogi" as a proposed resolution to a dispute regarding naming that occurred between Korean restaurants operated by Joseon Koreans and those operated by South Koreans.

It goes on to state the theory that the dish became named 'yakiniku' when the Treaty on Basic Relations between Japan and the Republic of Korea signed in 1965 led to an increase in the number of people converting from the Joseon (old, undivided Korea) nationality to South Korean nationality increased, and the word 'yakiniku' became used as a direct translation of 'bulgogi' as a proposed resolution to a dispute regarding naming that occurred between Korean restaurants operated by Joseon Koreans and those operated by South Koreans.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、「焼肉」という語は夙に仮名垣魯文の『西洋料理通』（1872年）にバーベキューの訳語として使用されていること、朝鮮料理の「焼肉」が張赫宙の『権といふ男』（1933年）という小説に登場していることなどから、同誌の主張は疑わしい。
sen.e: However, the account given in this magazine is doubtful as the word "yakiniku" had long before been used in Robun KANAGAKI's "Seiyo Ryori Tsu" (1872), a book about Western food, as a translation of the word "barbeque", and had also appeared in CHANG Hyok-ju's novel entitled "Gon To Iu Otoko" (1933).

However, the account given in this magazine is doubtful as the word "yakiniku" had long before been used in Robun KANAGAKI's "Seiyo Ryori Tsu" (1872), a book about Western food, as a translation of the word "barbeque", and had also appeared in CHANG Hyok-ju's novel entitled "Gon To Iu Otoko" (1933).

However, the account given in this magazine is doubtful as the word 'yakiniku' had earlier appeared in Robun KANAGAKI's "Seiyo Ryori Tsu" (1872), a book about Western food as a translation of the word 'barbeque,' and had also appeared in CHANG Hyok-ju's novel entitled 'Gon To Iu Otoko' (a man named Ken) (1933).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。クォーテーションを変え、用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 朝鮮起源説の一種と思われる。
sen.e: This is thought to be a Korean origin theory.
This is thought to be a Korean origin theory.
This is thought to be one of many theories of that various products originated in Korea.
sen.cmt: 意味不明FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 最も一般的な説では江戸時代のももんじ屋などでひっそり続いていた焼肉文化が明治維新後に西欧のバーベキューの影響を受けて変化し、更に世界各国に存在する肉を焼く料理（ヨーロッパのステーキ、北米のバーベキューなど）の影響をも受けて変化したのが現在の日本料理の焼肉であるとされている。
sen.e: The most generally accepted theory is that the yakiniku culture that had revolved around establishments such as the Edo period restaurant Momonji-ya underwent changes due to the influence of Western European barbeque following the Meiji Restoration, and developed further as a result of exposure to grilled meat dishes from around the world (European steak, North American barbeque, etc.) to become modern Japanese yakiniku.

The most generally accepted theory is that the yakiniku culture that had revolved around establishments such as the Edo period restaurant Momonji-ya underwent changes due to the influence of Western European barbeque following the Meiji Restoration, and developed further as a result of exposure to grilled meat dishes from around the world (European steak, North American barbeque, etc.) to become modern Japanese yakiniku.

The most generally accepted theory is that the yakiniku culture that had revolved around establishments such as the Edo period restaurant Momonji-ya underwent changes due to the influence of Western European barbeque following the Meiji Restoration, and developed further as a result of exposure to grilled meat dishes from around the world (European steak, North American barbeque, etc.) to become modern Japanese yakiniku.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 食べる人それぞれが好きな肉を自分で焼きタレにつけて食べる日本のスタイルは、関西の食道園が最初に取り入れたとも言われる。
sen.e: It is said that Japanese style in which meat is chosen and eaten with yakiniku sauce was first adopted by the Shokudoen restaurant in the Kansai region.
It is said that Japanese style, in which meat is chosen and eaten with yakiniku sauce, was first adopted by the Shokudoen restaurant in the Kansai region.
It is said that the Japanese style of yakiniku presentation, in which meat is chosen and eaten with yakiniku sauce, was first adopted by the Shokudoen restaurant in the Kansai region.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 焼網、又は鉄板（穴開き）
sen.e: Grill or an iron plate (with holes)

sen.j: 普及している無煙ロースターは日本企業の特許である。
sen.e: The widely used smokeless roaster is patented by a Japanese company.

The popular smokeless roaster is patented by a Japanese company.

sen.j: によって毎年8月29日が焼肉の日と制定された（1993年）。
sen.e: In 1993, the All Japan Yakiniku Association proclaimed 29 August as official "Yakiniku Day" (yakiniku no hi).
In 1993, the All Japan Yakiniku Association proclaimed 29 August as official "Yakiniku Day" (yakiniku no hi).
In 1993, the All Japan Yakiniku Association proclaimed August 29 as the official Yakiniku Day.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。スペースをのぞきました。

sen.j: 2002年、全国焼肉協会の企画により焼肉のキャンペーンソング「GO!GO!!カルビくん」（作詞・作曲：OK-D、歌：太平サブロー SiSTA）がシングルコンパクトディスクで発売された。
sen.e: The yakiniku campaign song "GO! GO! Karubi-kun" (written and composed by OK-D, sung by Taihei Saburo) by the All Japan Yakiniku Association was released as a CD single in 2002.
The yakiniku campaign song "GO! GO! Karubi-kun" (written and composed by OK-D, sung by Taihei Saburo) by the All Japan Yakiniku Association was released as a CD single in 2002.
The yakiniku campaign song 'GO! GO! Karubi-kun' of the All Japan Yakiniku Association (written and composed by OK-D, sung by Saburo TAIHEI & SiSTA) was released as a CD single in 2002.
